title: Worley makes national interest pitch as Dar Group looms
text:
Engineering giant WorleyParsons is believed to be pushing back against its biggest shareholder Dar Group, arguing the Middle Eastern contractor is seeking to take governance control of the ASX-listed company in a move that would be against Australia's national interest.

Street Talk has obtained a confidential and detailed defence of Worley dubbed "Worley and the National Interest" which is understood to have been prepared by the company and sent to the Foreign Investment Review Board.

The 36-page document says Worley was a globally significant Australian company with capabilities and networks that were highly valuable in the resolution of strategic challenges facing Australia and the world.

Dar Group is WorleyParsons' biggest shareholder with a 23 per cent stake. Robert Shakespeare

It says it is the Worley board's clear understanding that Dar Group was seeking control of the Australian company – a matter that had been disclosed in meetings between the companies' respective chairmen and as recently as July 4.

"At these meetings, Dar Group has stated its intention to continue to increase its shareholding, to seek governance control by appointing two nominees including a Dar Group executive to the Worley board and to seek operational control through joint business initiatives," the report says.
